results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Beautiful Ballarat [Edited Version]
results.brief_description:
This film captures the beauty found in the city of Ballarat through the seasons. Highlights include the Begonia Festival, the Avenue of Honour monument and other local historic landmarks.

The footage was filmed by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, and presented in this edited version with music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: The Last Tram
results.brief_description:
This film captured by John ‘Jack’ Anderson, documents the last tram ride through the city of Ballarat in 1971.

The footage was filmed in 1971, with titles and music added for an event held at the Regent Theatre in Ballarat on 5th March 2020, “Large as Life: celebrating the life John ‘Jack’ Anderson”.

results.title: [Remix: Historic Melbourne]
results.brief_description:
This video was created using footage from the ACMI Collection.

The remix features trams and historic landmarks in the City of Melbourne. Selected locations include the Princes Bridge, Flinders Street Station, corner of Spring and Bourke Street, intersection of Flinders and Swanston Street, ‘South Melb’ tram, Flinders Street Station Clocktower from Elizabeth Street, St Paul’s Cathedral, Forum Theatre, ‘Melbourne Public Library’ (State Library of Victoria) and the banks of the Yarra River.

results.title: [Remix: Summer beaches and pools]
results.brief_description: This remix of films from the ACMI Collection features footage of people sunbathing, playing at beaches during warm summers in Victoria. Notably, people are seen lounging around and diving into the Beaurepaire Pool, Melbourne’s first 50-metre Olympic-size swimming pool, formerly located on Batman Avenue.

results.title: [Remix: Victorian Road Signs]
results.brief_description:
Produced using footage from the ACMI Collection, this remix features painted road signs from locations all over Victoria, interspliced with shots of native wildlife and natural wilderness.

Road signs in order of appearance are: Halls Gap, Horsham, McKenzie Falls, Murray Valley Highway, Corryon, Walwa, Tumbarumba, Jingellic, Upper Kiewa Valley Road, Mt Beauty, Rocky Valley, Princes Highway, Gembrook, Cockatoo, Whitfield, Wangaratta, Ferntree Gully, Wilson’s Promontory National Park, Ovens River, Beechworth, San Remo, Porepunkah, Murray River, Anglesea and Great Ocean Road.

results.title: What Do We Want?
results.creator_credit: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O'Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.credit_line:
2022
Reko Rennie, Kamilaroi
Three-channel video
Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description: What Do We Want draws on 1970s Blaxploitation films and Rennie’s own martial arts practice to explore political, environmental and social questions through an Aboriginal Australian lens.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Carlo Zeccola, Molly O’Connor, Philippa Campey, Film Camp and Reko Rennie
results.description:
An army of First Nations warriors come out to play in this latest action-packed video by Kamilaroi artist Reko Rennie.

An all-Indigenous crew of martial arts students train together in their dojo; learning teachings of discipline, self-defense and teamwork. When the Sensei cries, “What do we want?” the students respond, “Restitution! Land back! Equality! No more cops killing our mob!”, vocalising demands of environmental, political and social concern, and reflecting the broad diversity within contemporary Indigenous urban society.

Rennie was taught martial arts by his father while growing up in Melbourne’s inner West. What Do We Want? marries his 25-year history of martial arts and his arts practice, while expanding Rennie’s evolving moving image repertoire into the realm of performance.

What Do We Want? takes influence from martial arts films including Blaxploitation films of the 1970s and 80s; utilising the medium to make a statement about authenticity, respect, bravery and collective power. The students in What Do We Want? become a force to be reckoned with.

Displayed in the gallery in a massive three-channel video installation, the work loudly and proudly conveys the diversity of First Nations peoples, and the ongoing fight for justice that unifies them, raising urgent questions that require action and response.

Acknowledgements

Produced by Film Camp, Philippa Campey, Molly O’Connor

Original composition by A.B. Original

results.title: Darling Darling
results.creator_credit: Sam Smith, Bridget Ikin and Gabriella Hirst
results.credit_line:
Gabriella Hirst
Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound, 25:30 mins.
SanDisk Memory Card, gold leaf, in collaboration with Barbara Dabrowa, AGNSW Senior Conservator of Fine Arts – Frames
Courtesy the artist
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission, ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Two-channel video installation, digital video, sound and gilded SD card
results.brief_description:
Darling Darling presents two contrasting but linked responses to the idea of conservation. One side of the screen shows the meticulous care taken to restore WC Piguenit’s prized 1895 painting of the Barka-Darling River, The flood in the Darling, 1890, while the other side reveals the present-day neglect of the river itself. Excess upstream water diversion and climate change have contributed to severe water scarcity and mass fish kills in recent years.

In composing her shots of the river, Hirst references Australia’s beloved landscape painting tradition, and colonial-era artists like Eugene von Guérard, John Glover, Conrad Martens, Nicholas Chevalier, Ludwig Becker and of course, WC Piguenit. While their romantic paintings capture a sense of nature as awe inspiring, they also served the more material purpose of framing resources to be owned and exploited by European settlers, a visual expression of the concept of terra nullius.

Darling Darling invites us to question the role played by Western visual art traditions in shaping the value systems that allow such an extreme environmental crisis to unfold right before our eyes.

Gabriella Hirst (she/her) is an artist. She was born and grew up on Cammeraygal land (Australia) and is currently living between Berlin and London. She works primarily with moving image, performance, and with the garden as a site of critique and care. Gabriella’s practice and research explores connections between various manifestations of capture and control – spanning plant taxonomies, landscape painting, art conservation and nuclear history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sam Smith, Bridget Ikin and Gabriella Hirst

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bell, William M. Carty and Cinesound
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
